clinical_study.brief_title: Perioperative TEAS to Improve Post Cardiac Surgery Immunosuppression: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial
clinical_study.official_title: Perioperative TEAS to Improve Post Cardiac Surgery Immunosuppression: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Cardiac surgery usually leads to postoperative immunosuppression, which is characterized by predisposition to develop secondary nosocomial infections and high risk of tumorigenesis and development. Current studies showed that acupuncture treatment was effective on immunoregulation. Our previous study proved that electroacupuncture (EA) can regulate the innate immune system overreaction to endotoxin and reduce excessive inflammatory response induced by myocardial ischemia and reperfusion. However, whether transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation(TEAS) can improve immune function in patients post cardiac surgery is not clear. The investigators perform a randomized controlled study to evaluate whether TEAS treatment can improve the immunosuppression post cardiac surgery, which may provide rational for the development of TEAS to treat cardiac patients perioperatively.

primary_outcome.measure: Change of Monocyte HLA-DR(human leucocyte antigen DR)expression

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of Monocyte HLA-DR(human leucocyte antigen DR)expression

arm_group.description: Patients allocated in the Non TEAS group recieve the electrode patch on the skin, connected electro-acupuncture device, with no current input.

TEAS is a kind of treatment combining transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) with traditional Chinese acupuncture points, and inputs a specific low frequency pulse current into the body through skin.Patients allocated in the TEAS group receive standardised treatment at 2 acupuncture points (ST36 and BL23). The investigator put the electrode patch on the skin, connected electro-acupuncture device, and select the maximum current intensity patients can endure. The acupuncture treatment starts from 30min prior to operation to the end of surgery, and then four times within 48 hours post operation, 30 minutes for each time.
Patients allocated in the control group do not receive any intervention.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 1. Age: 18 to 75 years old; Gender: not limited; 2. Diagnosis for coronary heart disease or valvular heart disease, and patients scheduled for elective surgery; 3. Body mass index (BMI): 18<BMI≤31 kg.m-2; 4. American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA) physical status classification: Ⅰ-Ⅲ; 5. Signing informed consent; 6. CABG or valve operation performed for the first time.
Exclusion Criteria:
- 1. The meridians of Zhongfu, Yunmen, Lieque and Neiguan acupoints with the operative incision or scar; 2. Local skin infection in acupoints; 3. Upper or lower extremity nerve injury patients; 4. Spinal operation history; 5. Participating in other clinical trials within four weeks; 6. Cardiac pacemaker; 8. Patients who have preoperative pain and are using central analgesic medications. Opiate addiction, and dependence; 9. The patients with serious diseases of the central nervous system and severe mental illness in pre-operation. 10. Emergency bypass surgery.
